{{Infobox event | title = World Youth Day 1987 | image = | image_size = | caption = | date = {{start date|1987|04|06}} – {{end date|1987|04|12}} | time = | type = Youth festival | theme = "We have recognized the love that God has for us, and we have believed in it." "Hemos conocido y hemos creído en el amor que Dios nos holds". ([[First Epistle of John|1 Jn]] 4:16) | place = [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] | coordinates = | organisers = [[Catholic Church]] | participants = [[Pope John Paul II]] | website = http://www.vatican.va/gmg/years/gmg_1987_sp.html }} The second '''World Youth Day 1987''' took place on 6 and 12 April 1987 in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] and was presided by [[Pope John Paul II]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/gmg/years/gmg_1987_po.html|title=II Jornada Mundial da Juventude 1987|website=www.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.totus2us.com/universal/argentina/wyd-jmj-buenos-aires-1987/|title=Papa San Juan Pablo II en la JMJ 1987 Buenos Aires - Totus2us|website=www.totus2us.com|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>It was the first edition held in a city other than [[Rome]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314090405/http://www.rio2013.com/es/a-jornada/historia-da-jornada|title=Historia de la jornada - Jornada Mundial De La Juventud 2013|date=14 March 2012|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
==Official announce==
The headquarters of the 2nd edition of [[World Youth Day|WYD]] was made official by John Paul II on June 8, 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://w2.vatican.va/content/john-paul-ii/es/messages/youth/documents/hf_jp-ii_mes_30111986_ii-world-youth-day.html|title=II Jornada Mundial de la Juventud, 1987 - Juan Pablo II|website=w2.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
==Theme== The theme chosen by Pope John Paul II for these days is taken from the fourth chapter of the [[First Epistle of John]], verse 16: "And we have recognized the love that God has for us, and we have believed in it".
==Anthem== The anthem of these World Youth Days was titled "a nuevo sol" ("a new sun").
==Procedure== The WYD of 1987 took place as part of the John Paul's [[List of pastoral visits of Pope John Paul II outside Italy| apostolic trip]] to [[Uruguay]] and [[Argentina]] which took place from March 31 to April 12, 1987. The Pope arrived in Argentina on 6 April.
===11 April=== The opening Mass was held in the [[Basilica of Our Lady of Luján]], on April 11, 1987. The Vigil prior to the closing Mass was divided into three blocks: Argentine, Latin American and World, for each the Pope directed a different message.
===12 April=== The central act was the closing mass celebrated in front of the [[Obelisco de Buenos Aires]], on April 12th, [[Palm Sunday]], in front of over a million people and was the first time that a Pope celebrated a Palm Sunday outside of Rome.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/fc?cmd=art&codid=20.0.1341315534&DocRulesView=Libero&chId=30|title=Il Sole 24 ORE: finanza, economia, esteri, valute, borsa e fisco|first=Il Sole 24 ORE - Redazione|last=online|website=www.ilsole24ore.com|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523061615/http://rio2013.com/pt/noticias/detalhes/1765/buenos-aires-1987-relembre-a-primeira-jmj-latino-americana|title=Buenos Aires 1987: relembre a primeira JMJ latino-americana - JMJ Rio 2013|date=23 May 2013|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
==Audience==
More than 1 million young people from all over the world gathered at the [[9 de Julio Avenue]] in the Argentine capital to participate in the conference.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.2016wyd.eu/?pl_world-youth-day-buenos-aires-1987,21|title=Buenos Aires 1987 - Swiatowe Dni Młodziezy Kraków 2016|website=www.2016wyd.eu|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.camineo.info/news/150/ARTICLE/16432/2011-08-16.html|title=Río de Janeiro será sede de la próxima JMJ 2013|first=|last=AICA|website=www.camineo.info|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>Its central ceremonies took place at Plaza de Constitución, one of the largest squares of the Argentine capital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sdm.nowysacz.pl/en/wyd-2016/history-of-wyd/|title=History of WYD – Week Missionary 20-26 July 2016|website=sdm.nowysacz.pl|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
==The Cross== The Cross of the World Youth Day was a wooden [[Crucifix|crucifix]]of 3.8 [[Metre|m]] height given to [[Catholic Church|young Catholics]] by Pope John Paul II at the end of the [[Jubilee (Christianity)|Holy Year]] of 1984 with the words "Take it for the world as a sign of the love of the Lord Jesus."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.madridactual.es/20110814280583/la-jornada-mundial-de-la-juventud-la-fe-que-une-a-los-jovenes.html|title=La Jornada Mundial de la Juventud: la fe que une a los jóvenes|first=Madrid|last=Actual|date=14 August 2011|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>For the first time since its institution, the Cross out of Rome to be one of the main symbols of WYD in Buenos Aires 1987.
==Hymn of the World Youth Day 1987==
THE NEW CIVILIZATION
The WYD Hymn of Buenos Aires 1987, popularly known as "Un Nuevo Sol" was composed by Alberto Croce and Eugenio Perpetua.
A land that has no borders but hands that together will form a stronger chain that war and that death.
We know it, love is the path
A more just and fraternal homeland where we all build unity where nobody is displaced, because all are called.
We know...
A new sun rises about the new civilization that is born today. A stronger chain that hate and that death We know it, love is the path.
Justice is the force of peace love, who makes forgive. The truth, the force that gives us liberation.
We know...
The one who has shares his wealth and the one who knows does not impose his truth. The boss understands that power is a service.
We know...
The one who believes contagious with his life and the pain is covered with love because the man feels supportive in solidarity with the world.
We know...<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/pontifical_councils/laity/documents/rc_pc_laity_doc_20020324_hymns-youth-days_it.html#UN|title=Inni delle Giornate Mondiali della Gioventù|website=www.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>

'''Yahya ibn Umar ibn Yahya ibn Husayn ibn [[Zayd ibn Ali]] [[Zayn al-Abidin]] ibn [[Husayn ibn Ali|Al-Husayn]] ibn [[Ali|Ali al-Murtada]]'''<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=nxyl-gp36y8C&pg=PA105&dq=Yahya+ibn+Umar&lr=&as_brr=3&cd=173#v=onepage&q=Yahya%20ibn%20Umar&f=false Incipient decline, By Ṭabarī, Joel L. Kraemer, pg.105-106]</ref> was an [[Descendants of Ali ibn Abi Talib|Alid]] Imam. His mother was '''Umm al-Husayn Fatimah bint al-Husayn ibn Abdallah ibn Ismail ibn [[Abdullah ibn Ja'far|Abdullah]] ibn [[Ja`far ibn Abī Tālib]].''' <ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=RK8frlO37CoC&pg=PA16&dq=Yahya+ibn+Umar&lr=&as_brr=3&cd=157#v=onepage&q=Yahya%20ibn%20Umar&f=false The crisis of the ʻAbbāsid Caliphate, By Ṭabarī, George Saliba, pg.15]</ref> In the days of the [[Abbasid]] [[Caliph]] [[Al-Musta'in]], he marched out from [[Kufa]] and lead an abortive uprising from Kufa in 250 A.H. (864-65 C.E.),<ref>Incipient decline, By Tabarī, Joel L. Kraemer, pg.106</ref> but was killed by the Abbasid forces led by [[Al-Husayn ibn Isma'il al-Mus'abi|Hussain ibn Isma’il]], who had been sent to deal with him.
==Sequence of events of Yahya’s life== [[File:Iraq-CIA WFB Map.png|right|thumb|250px|Map of Iraq, where Yahya ibn Umar conducted his revolt]] The following is a sequence of events of Yahya’s life: *In 850 C.E. [[Al-Mutawakkil]] brought Yahya from one of the Abbasid provinces in order to punish him, after he had reportedly assembled a group of supporters. Umar ibn Faraj al-Rukhkhaj [[Al-Sijistani]]<ref>Incipient decline, By Tabarī, Joel L. Kraemer, pg.74</ref> (one of the Abbasid’s official secretaries who had purchased land for the founding of [[Samarra]])<ref>Incipient decline, By Ṭabarī, Joel L. Kraemer, pg.35, 62</ref> flogged him 18 lashes and he was incarcerated in [[Baghdad]] in the Matbaq Prison before being released.<ref>Incipient decline, By Ṭabarī, Joel L. Kraemer, pg.105-106</ref> *Yahya was hard pressed by his creditors and sought a grant from Umar ibn Faraj, but was harshly denied. He thus cursed Umar ibn Faraj and as a result was imprisoned, but was later set free. He then moved to live in Baghdad, but was still suffering from hardship. He then went to Samarra where he met another man whom he asked for a grant, but was again harshly denied.<ref>The crisis of the ʻAbbāsid Caliphate, By Ṭabarī, George Saliba, pg.15</ref> *Yahya then went to Kufa, where he rebelled in 864 C.E. His uprising seems to have been a rash course of action. In Kufa, Yahya gathered a great throng of Bedouins and a contingent of Kufa also rallied around him. He then marched to [[Fallujah|Al-Fallujah]] and encamped at a village known as al-‘Umud. He then marched to Kufa and proceeded as far as the treasury, where he took whatever he found. Following this, he declared his rebellion in Kufa. He then liberated the two prisons of Kufa of all those interred. He then left Kufa for its agricultural hinterland (the [[Sawad]]) and settled in a place called Bustan. He was followed and supported by a group of [[Zaidiyyah|Zaydis]], Bedouins living near Bustan and people from other certain places near Kufa. After establishing himself at Bustan his followers grew in number.<ref>The crisis of the ʻAbbāsid Caliphate, By Ṭabarī, George Saliba, pg.15-17]</ref> *Yahya routed an Abbasid force sent to defeat him in a fierce battle near the Kufa bridge.<ref>The crisis of the ʻAbbāsid Caliphate, By Ṭabarī, George Saliba, pg.17</ref> *The Zaydis propagandized that he was the chosen one (al-Rida) of [[Ahl al-Bayt|Muhammad’s family]]. This increased his popularity and even the mob of Baghdad held him in high esteem. In Kufa a group of experienced [[Shia|Shiites]] swore allegiance to him, along with other people. While he was in Kufa he was making preparations for his forces, while the Abbasid forces sent to defeat him were also making the necessary preparations.<ref name="Abbāsid Caliphate pg.18">The crisis of the ʻAbbāsid Caliphate, By Ṭabarī, George Saliba, pg.18</ref> *On the 13th [[Rajab]] (20 August) 864 C.E. he marched against the Abbasid forces of Hussain ibn Isma’il, after being urged to do so by his followers.<ref name="Abbāsid Caliphate pg.18"/> *The next day, Yahya’s forces attacked Hussain ibn Isma’il forces, but were defeated and fled, abandoning Yahya on the battlefield.<ref name="Abbāsid Caliphate pg.18"/> *Yahya was then beheaded on the battlefield in Rajab 250 A.H. (August 864 C.E.) and his head was mutilated. His head was then sent to Al-Musta'in, from where it was displayed at the public gate in Samarra.<ref>The crisis of the ʻAbbāsid Caliphate, By Ṭabarī, George Saliba, pg.19</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZY-HUxd2eRgC&pg=PA75&dq=Yahya+ibn+Umar&lr=&cd=23#v=onepage&q=Yahya%20ibn%20Umar&f=false Ibn Abī Ṭāhir Ṭayfūr and Arabic writerly culture: a ninth-century bookman in ..., By Shawkat M. Toorawa, pg.74]</ref>
Some of Yahya’s companions did not accept the news that he was defeated and killed. Instead, they believed that he was not killed and he only hid himself and went into [[The Occultation|occultation]] and that he was the [[Mahdi]] and the [[Al-Qa'im (person)|Qa’im]], who will reappear another time.
His revolt had an interesting sequel in 255 A.H. (868-69 C.E.), when ʿAlī ibn Muḥammad, the leader of the [[Zanj Rebellion]], claimed to be the incarnated form of Yahya.<ref> name="The History of al-Tabari Vol. 34 Incipient Decline" author="Ṭabarī, Joel L. Kraemer" pg.106</ref>
==Elegies written for Yahya== [[Al-Masudi]] mentions that many [[Elegy|elegies]] were written for Yahya, and that he had recorded some of them in his Kitab al-Awsat (The Middle Book). But in his book [[The Meadows of Gold]], it is the elegy by Ibn Abi Tahir Tayfur (which Al-Masudi alone had preserved) that he gives pride of place. Ibn Abi Tahir’s elegy on the crucified Zaydi rebel is composed of 14 lines and the poem was possibly recited in Samarra, where Yahya’s head was displayed, or else before the large crowds that are known to have gathered in Baghdad. In the elegy, Ibn Abi Tahir attacks the [[Sunni]] Abbasid Caliphal family for its usurpation of the rights of the house of Ali.<ref>Ibn Abī Ṭāhir Ṭayfūr and Arabic writerly culture: a ninth-century bookman in ..., By Shawkat M. Toorawa, pg.39, 74-75, 127</ref>
Ibn al-Rumi (d.283 A.H. / 896 C.E.) also published elegies on Yahya.<ref>Ibn Abī Ṭāhir Ṭayfūr and Arabic writerly culture: a ninth-century bookman in ..., By Shawkat M. Toorawa, pg.75</ref>
